column5: It almost still looks under-done? That one section in the middle at least. Which seems strange if you  baked for a total of 60m at that temp. Do you happen to have an oven thermometer to see if your oven is truly getting up to temp?

Gotcha! Thanks for clarifying. I definitely see how itâ€™d hard to engage or interject if she is constantly talking, especially if you feel that she doesnâ€™t like you. A basic tenant of the therapeutic process is holding unconditional positive regard for clients, and it sounds like she doesnâ€™t make you feel like she is following that. Itâ€™s also more challenging the more time has passed to address issues. Is there space at the beginning of your sessions to maybe say things youâ€™d like to talk about? Or maybe if you wrote the topic down on a list and showed her that youâ€™ve come with things on your mind youâ€™d like to discuss? Again, it seems like there are a few things that youâ€™re struggling with in regard to this therapist (feeling like she dislikes you, that you arenâ€™t able to discuss what you want to, and that she constantly talks and talks over you) and if you donâ€™t feel like youâ€™re able to use the space how you feel will be most beneficial for you it might be best to look for someone new?

Hello! Iâ€™m sorry to hear that your therapist talks over you and that it doesnâ€™t seem like youâ€™re getting what you need out of your sessions. When you first started seeing them did they ask about your goals for therapy? Iâ€™m wondering if youâ€™ve tried to talk about the assault that brought you to therapy and theyâ€™ve redirected the conversation or if neither of you have brought it up? As a therapist, itâ€™s always important for me to identify goals upfront with the client so we both have an understanding of the intention of our time together and what they want to get out of it. If working through that and symptoms of PTSD stemming from the assault are a goal you have, then it seems strange that itâ€™s never been spoken about. However, if you havenâ€™t attempted to bring it up and it wasnâ€™t addressed as a goal, the therapist might be taking your lead about the things that are on your mind to talk about. If thatâ€™s the case I would suggest saying, â€œhey, this is something Iâ€™ve been thinking about and would really like to start discussing with you.â€ If itâ€™s been set as a goal and hasnâ€™t been discussed yet, maybe something like, â€œIâ€™d really like to revisit the goals we set at the beginning and start discussing xyz.â€

Both of those statements really only work if you feel that you continue to want to see the same therapist. If youâ€™d rather seek out a new therapist because you donâ€™t feel like this person is a great match, thatâ€™s ok too! I always tell people that finding a therapist is like finding a good pair of shoes. You might have to try on a few pairs before you get a comfortable fit! And itâ€™s perfectly ok to two a therapist that you donâ€™t think itâ€™s working out with them!

Iâ€™m in the northeast US and just got my MSW in 2019. I know that many people in my program felt like they had to make a big adjustment in the way they spoke, especially about populations they hadnâ€™t worked with before. Seconding the above comment that the most important thing is to use person first language. So not a â€œdisabled personâ€ but a â€œperson with a disability.â€ The purpose for this is that people are so much more than a disability they have and when you use a label first thatâ€™s all people hear. I would never say physically or mentally challenged or handicapped, as these are pretty outdated terms. Itâ€™s also important to defer to how someone refers to themselves however, and different communities have reclaimed language and terms that once were used offensively towards them in an effort to reclaim that power. 

I think trying your best is the most important thing. In my classes we always set group norms at the beginning to make sure we addressed what class expectations for how we treated each other. One that often came up  was â€œpermission to speak as a draftâ€ and â€œassuming best intentionsâ€ so that if someone said something that made others cringe, we would all assume that person was doing their best with the current information they had and use it as an opportunity to have a discussion about how it could be said differently. A professor that I had multiple classes with said she always â€œspeaks with a comma, not a period, so that when she gets new information she is able to change her opinion.â€ 

A quote that has always stuck with me is from Maya Angelou, â€œyou do the best you can until you know better and once you know better, do better.â€

100% you should be getting hazard pay. I have my MSW and work as a clinician for an organization that is currently paying all of our residential workers that are continuing to work face to face with clients 1.5x their base pay plus any shift differentials. It goes up to 2x base pay if clients are covid-19 positive. Another similar, but slightly smaller, mental health agency in our county that has residential and a hospital diversion program is not offering a similar pay increase at that agency, which doesnâ€™t feel fair. 

I think you gather as much information that you can get about similarly positioned agencies and you use that to advocate! Your work is incredibly necessary and you should be compensated as such during this time where you are at an increased risk of exposure.

My partner and I once had an argument like this over the odor balls we keep in our winter boots because we hadnâ€™t been able to find them for months and then all of a sudden they were in my boots one morning when I went to put them on. The same boots that Iâ€™d been wearing everyday for months. I was so confused and assumed he had found them and put them in my boots, but when I mentioned it he had no idea what I was talking about. Then we were both like â€œwtf was it me?â€ but also still thinking it was the other person. Just laughing and not sure what to make of anything. Still an unsolved mystery!

I know quite a few people that didnâ€™t want to try teletherapy but then decided to give it a try now. Iâ€™ve had 3 appointments with my own therapist this way and though itâ€™s not my favorite (the silence seems more awkward and I feel weird if I pause and she is lagging so seems like sheâ€™s just staring at me) it has been nice to still see her and have time to talk and process all thatâ€™s going on. I am also a clinician and have been seeing my own clients via telehealth and had a few say no when I first offered, but then reach out to me and say they think it could be helpful and I was happy to hear from them and didnâ€™t judge at all that theyâ€™d initially said no. We are all going through this weird rollercoaster of emotions throughout this pandemic and all handling it differently. No judgement for where youâ€™re at! I say reach out.

I graduated with my MSW last year after completing a BS in Psychology! My focus has always been kids and families so I chose to work substitute shifts for a local mental health agency in one of their residential programs and their inpatient hospital diversion/crisis stabilization program. This was nice because I could sign up for shifts when I was able to around my internship and other part time job and was still getting experience in the field and working with folks in acute crisis.

Iâ€™m really sorry that happened. It sounds like a pretty terrible situation and Iâ€™m sure very unsettling to know that your boyfriend didnâ€™t let you know or give a warning. Iâ€™m glad that you were able to find a therapist and make an appointment with them. I hope it gets better for you soon!

Iâ€™m sorry that happened to you, that sounds really icky :( It sounds like since you didnâ€™t know the mashed potatoes had weed in them that maybe someone else made them? Iâ€™m wondering if you feel worried to eat food that you prepare or only food that you donâ€™t know the origin of/canâ€™t be sure is safe from any unknown ingredients? Could you potentially try to prepare most of your meals yourself for a few weeks? Or keep a few foods you know to be â€œsafeâ€ always on hand in case you arenâ€™t able to eat something that someone else made? I also think reaching out to a therapist could be helpful so that they can help work with you to find strategies and coping skills for calming yourself when you are starting to feel anxious. That definitely sounds like a hard experience and I think finding someone that is skilled in working with people with anxiety could really be helpful, along with trying to ensure you know the origin of your meals so it feels safer to eat as you are working through the anxiety piece. Eventually you will be able to branch out to eating meals that you donâ€™t have to investigate so thoroughly.
